Briefing 

Sleep disorders are situations that become evident because of changes in sleeping position. 

This condition is likely to affect your whole health and also your life. You can’t drive when depriving yourself of sleep, and you run the risk of other damaging health problems. 

Here are some of the early-symptoms of a sleep disorder; 

  • drowsiness in the daytime 
  •  uncontrolled daytime breathing 
  •  uncontrolled movement during sleep 
  • irregular wake and sleep short intervals
  • absolute difficulty to sleep 
  • irritability or anxiety
  • daytime fatigue
  • depression
  • lack of concentration

To delve in more further, here are common types of sleep disorders;

Insomnia: This is simply the difficulty of falling asleep. It is caused by stress, anxiety, jet lag, digestive problems and hormones. Sometimes, it is a symptom of other health problems. It is a big issue for a persons overall health or quality of life. According to Health reports in the United States alone, over 50 percent of American adults live with this problem. The disorder has been found to be common among women and older adults. 

This condition is commonly classified in three types:

  • constant insomnia (happening regularly for a month)
  • periodical insomnia (intermittent episodes)
  • transient insomnia (lasting for a few nights)

Restless legs syndrome: This is a type of sleep disorder which causes you to move your legs uncontrollably. And its also accompanied by a tingling sweet sensation in your legs. They occur in the day and also in the night. 

Sleep Apnea: You experience abnormal breathing episodes when you’re asleep. And there are several types. 

Narcolepsy: An extreme condition which makes a person sleep during the day and suddenly falls asleep during the night.

Luckily, there are many ways to treat sleep disorders, and when a physician finds the cause, he or she can be able to treat the patient effectively.

The cause of Sleep disorders

Presently, there are many found causes of a sleep disorders. In most cases, sleep disorders develop because of an extreme health issue.

Here is a little briefing on the causes; click link

Nocturia:

This is caused by uncontrolled urination in the night. A cause of this abnormality is, Hormonal imbalances or diseases of the urinary tract. Call your doctor, if you do observe such issues.

Respiratory Problems and Allergy problems:

Colds, allergy issues and respiratory infections can disrupt a persons breathe in the night. The inability to breathe smoothly through the nose can also cause this problem.

Constant pain:

Having constant pain can make it difficult to fall asleep. Most times, you even wake up after falling asleep. Some of the causes are:

  • arthritis
  • fibromyalgia
  • inflammatory bowel
  • chronic lower back pain
  • constant headaches
  • chronic fatigue syndrome

Anxiety and Stress:

Less sleep is also caused by stress and anxiety. When in such a state it is difficult to fall asleep. Factors also noticed with such problem are, sleep walking, nightmares, and sleep talking.

Diagnoses

The first thing your doctor would have to do is to perform a physical examination and gather the information needed. They’re also likely to other tests like;

  • genetic blood test: a blood test done to treat narcolepsy and other health conditions that might be the cause of a patients sleeping problems.
  • Polysomnography: this is a full examination that tests for oxygen levels, brain waves and body movements.
  • electroencephalogram: a test done to assess electrical activity and flow in the brain.

These tests are important and also good in determining the right procedures to be used in treating sleep disorders.

How Sleep Disorders are treated

Doctors treat sleep disorders using different methods and they’re;

Lifestyle changes

To have good results, doctors do recommend having a change of lifestyle. Sometimes including it with medical treatments. Things to consider in this process are;

  • changing your diets
  • reducing anxiety or stress
  • drinking less water before going to bed
  • limiting caffeine intake in the afternoon
  • decreasing alcohol and tobacco use
  • sticking to a regular sleep schedule
  • eating a small quantity of carbs before bedtime

Medical treatments

This includes any of the following;

  • melatonin supplements
  • sleeping pills
  • dental guard (usually to grind teeth)
  • cold or allergy medication

In essence, the effects of sleep disorders can be so frustrating that you’ll need immediate relief. But unfortunately, long term cases can take more time to resolve. Furthermore, if you follow the treatment plan as given to you by your doctor, then they’ll be a quick recovery.
